MAQUIAR.TITLE: MaquiAR
MAQUIAR.HEADLINE: MaquiAR: An augmented reality makeup try-on app using ARCore
MAQUIAR.TEXT: I developed the MaquiAR app as part of my undergraduate thesis for the Bachelor of Information Systems program at Universidade Federal de Santa Catarina (UFSC). The app allows users to try on makeup virtually before making online purchases.
MAQUIAR.READMORE:
The Android app was written mostly in Kotlin with some parts in Java. It uses ARCore to utilize Augmented Reality.

Features:

  • List the makeups
  • Makeup description page
  • Makeup try on
  • Change the makeup without leaving try on screen
  • Add, remove and visualize favorite makeups
  • Take photos and share in social media
  • Redirect the user to the website he can buy the makeup

In order to reutilize the textures for different makeup colors, I created a white texture and used Open GL Shading Language (GLSL) to give it different colors. Since white has value (1,1,1) it is multiplication neutral element, so I can just multiply the white texture with the color of the makeup.

The System Usability Scale (SUS) questionnaire was applied to 10 students and MaquiAR's average score was 88.5.

HSSETREVIEWBOT.TITLE: Set Review Bot
HSSETREVIEWBOT.HEADLINE: Twitch chat bot to help Hearthstone set reviews
HSSETREVIEWBOT.TEXT:
Hearthstone is a popular turn-based digital collectible card game boasting millions of active players. Each year, the game releases between 3 and 4 new sets, introducing fresh cards and strategies. In anticipation of these expansions, prominent players and streamers provide set reviews, offering their insights on the new cards.

To enhance viewer engagement, I developed a bot that integrates the audience into the review process. The bot allows viewers to share their personal ratings for the cards directly through Twitch chat. These ratings are then collected and stored in a Google Sheets document for reference.

For the technical implementation, I utilized Node, Express, OAuth2, JWT, MongoDB (Mongoose), tmi.js, and Google Sheets API. In addition, I created a simple frontend using React, which I deployed on Heroku
HSSETREVIEWBOT.READMORE:
• 1140 different people rated cards
  • Total of 18221 ratings were given for the 135 cards
  • 32777 twitch chat messages were read

HSSETREVIEWSITE.TITLE: Set Review Hub
HSSETREVIEWSITE.HEADLINE: Hearthstone Set Review Hub
HSSETREVIEWSITE.TEXT:
After being praised for the Set Review Bot, I decided to evolve it into a plataform to centralize information about card reviews and let any user create their own, while still providing the bot for streamers record their chat's ratings for each card.

Keeping the same backend from the Set Review Bot, I decided to change the frontend to Angular with PrimeNG components, techs that I am more familiar with, being able to deploy it in time for the "Showdown in the Badlands" expansion, released in November 2023. In a week, more than 80 users created an account in the system.

After deployment, people reach me out willing to contribute to the project, which made me adapt the project to follow community standards for open-source. One of those developers was a member of Untapped.gg (company that created the most popular Deck Tracker tool for Hearthstone), and provided data about the cards after the expansion release.

With that data, I and a friend of mine trained classification models, using Python libraries Pandas and scikit-learn, to give ratings to the cards based on their popularity and winrate. The model achieved a satisfying accuracy (around 74%) and we used those ratings to compare to the users before expansion ratings and to rank the best reviews.
HSSETREVIEWSITE.READMORE:
For the second expansion after the website is live, it reached even better results:

  • 230 users logged in and rated at least 1 cards
  • Over 700 users rated cards concurrently via Twitch chat interactions.
  • The platform also gained visibility among prominent streamers, including the current world champion

URLSHORTENER.TITLE: URL Shortener
URLSHORTENER.HEADLINE: A URL shortener, like tinyURL
URLSHORTENER.TEXT:
I developed this application as part of a coding test for a company, and I'm pleased to mention that I was ultimately hired by them. The application's purpose is to generate shortened URLs for any given URL input. Additionally, it retains a history of the last URLs that users have shortened.

The project was designed to meet specific system requirements provided in the coding test:

  • The website should allow users to input an original URL and generate a unique code with five or fewer characters
  • The generated short URL must remain valid indefinitely, and even if the same original URL is entered multiple times, the resulting short URL must be different each time
  • Upon accessing the short URL, users should be instantly redirected to the original URL, ensuring minimal delay
URLSHORTENER.READMORE:
The back-end application was developed using Java with Spring Boot. JPA (Java Persistence API) and PostgreSQL were employed for database management.

This application comprises two main endpoints: a POST endpoint for generating short URLs based on input URLs, and a GET endpoint for redirecting users to the original websites using short URLs. If the provided short URL is valid, the user is redirected; otherwise, they are directed to the front-end error page.

To fulfill the requirements, the following strategies were adopted:

  • Upon receiving a URL, a unique sequential ID is generated. This ID increments sequentially, ensuring uniqueness even in concurrent scenarios.
  • The unique ID is then encoded to base62, resulting in a short URL composed of numbers, lowercase, and uppercase letters.
  • For retrieving the original URL from the short URL, the encoded short URL is decoded to obtain the corresponding ID in the database.

Despite making short URLs predictable (which could pose a security risk), sequential IDs were chosen (using JPA's GeneratedValue) to ensure uniqueness even in scenarios involving concurrency.

The front-end application was developed using Angular and utilizes Angular Material components for its user interface.

The interface design is clean and simple, offering an intuitive user experience.

To maintain a history of shortened URLs, user data is stored in the browser's local storage.

MOREABOUTME.HEADLINE: A bit about my hobbies
MOREABOUTME.TEXT:
My hobbies encompass a range of interests, including sports (particularly football ‚öΩ), video games üéÆ, music üéµ, and country trivia üåç. I've learned so many facts about countries that made me want to visit all them, and I will!

During my youth, I played football in Brazilian first-division youth teams, an experience that made me very disciplined and hard worker.

Amid the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020, I ventured into competitive Hearthstone. Hearthstone is a turn-based digital collectible card game between two opponents, using constructed decks of 30 cards along with a selected hero with a unique power. In that year:

  • I consistently secured top positions on the ranked ladder (I'm the third Brazilian with the most ladder finishes)
  • I achieved top 10 and top 8 finishes in the last two ESL Brazilian Premier Leagues.
  • I participated in 2 Masters Tours, which are the top-tier Hearthstone tournaments
  • I peaked at rank 2 of Asia-Pacific server and rank 7 of Americas'
  • I created one of the best decks ever (6D Warlock)
  • I crafted several other successful decks

During this period, I collaborated with world-renowned players within practice groups. In these groups, I played a pivotal role as the imaginative and innovative member, constantly devising new strategies. My proficiency in English significantly improved as I engaged in multiple chats and frequent voice calls. I even streamed in English to a public of over 900 people.

In 2021, I immersed myself in Sporcle trivia challenges, mastering the flags of every country worldwide. Notably, I can accurately pinpoint each country on a map, even without borderlines!
